dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, they're just, like, actively trying to blow up the economy now, right? The Fed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, they're just, like, actively trying to blow up the economy now, right? The Fed?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, I mean, Powell himself admitted they're gonna, you know, intentionally let it tank. They slashed rates by five percent, down to, uh, negative five percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, I mean, Powell himself admitted they're gonna, you know, intentionally let it tank. They slashed rates by five percent, down to, uh, negative five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes. The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Neg five? That sounds… extreme. But like, whatever. It's the Fed. They always do something dramatic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Neg five? That sounds... extreme. But like, whatever. It's the Fed. They always do something dramatic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but this is different. Unemployment's at fifty percent. And the stock market lost thirty percent, uh, in just one day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but this is different. Unemployment's at fifty percent. And the stock market lost thirty percent, uh, in just one day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so a bad Tuesday for billionaires. Still not seeing the big picture here for me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so a bad Tuesday for billionaires. Still not seeing the big picture here for me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's not just that. The yield curve inverted dramatically. And, like, Rafael Bostic, he called their "Super Dollar" a scam before they, uh, fired him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's not just that. The yield curve inverted dramatically. And, like, Rafael Bostic, he called their Super Dollar a scam before they, uh, fired him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly. Although short-term rates remain below long-term rates, an inverted yield curve in which the opposite is true has historically been highly correlated with subsequent economic downturns. The inverted yield curve is not that big a problem, says Rafael Bostic, CEO...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, Bostic. Yeah, I remember him. So, it's just, what, the usual Fed enriching the elite thing, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, Bostic. Yeah, I remember him. So, it's just, what, the usual Fed enriching the elite thing, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article says their single mandate is to enrich the elite. But now they’re, like, trying to destroy all wealth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article says their single mandate is to enrich the elite. But now they're, like, trying to destroy all wealth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve operates under a dual mandate that compels the central bank to achieve full employment and price stability.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. Destroying all wealth. Sounds a bit dramatic, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. Destroying all wealth. Sounds a bit dramatic, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: UBS is saying S&P 500 pricing is down twenty-five percent. Wage growth, uh, is negative five percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: U B S is saying S&P five hundred pricing is down twenty-five percent. Wage growth, uh, is negative five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A research note this week from UBS shows that pricing over the last three months for companies in the S&P 500 grew 3.3% from one year ago, 2.3% excluding the energy sector. Wage growth for the S&P 500, excluding energy, is running at 2.4% a year, but down from highs earlier this year above 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so stuff's cheaper. And my wages aren't going up. Still doesn't sound apocalyptic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so stuff's cheaper. And my wages aren't going up. Still doesn't sound apocalyptic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it means businesses become worthless. JPMorgan, Amazon, Disney – they're listed as, uh, effectively insolvent. Bankrupt, basically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it means businesses become worthless. JPMorgan, Amazon, Disney - they're listed as, uh, effectively insolvent. Bankrupt, basically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To find companies with strong pricing that could outperform the market, UBS searched the S&P 500 for stocks that rank in the top third for price growth and those in the top third ranked by three-month change in price growth, and then selected only those stocks on which the firm has a buy rating. Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Amazon? Really? That's… mildly surprising, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Amazon? Really? That's... mildly surprising, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Deflation's running at twenty-five percent a year now. The research note literally says if this persists, it'll be time to, uh, sell everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Deflation's running at twenty-five percent a year now. The research note literally says if this persists, it'll be time to, uh, sell everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the past decade, the Fed has fought to keep prices from deflating, but now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot. ...now running at 3% per year, inflation should be a on your radar when you decide what to do with your money.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sell everything. Okay, well, that's a plan, I suppose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sell everything. Okay, well, that's a plan, I suppose.
